title: Chicago Humanities Festival: Simon Critchley—Tragedy, the Greeks, and Us
title_display: Chicago Humanities Festival: Simon Critchley—Tragedy, the Greeks, and Us
hero_caption: Simon Critchley. Photo courtesy of the artist.
description:
To understand modern times, says New School philosopher Simon Critchley, we must look to the ancient world. Critchley, who moderates the Stone, the New York Times's weekly philosophy column, makes a compelling case for this approach in his latest book, Tragedy, the Greeks, and Us, arguing that a time as fraught as ours demands we turn not to pop psychology but to the intensely alive works of antiquity, whose creations reveal the universal, eternal motivations of humanity. Critchley illuminates these themes, providing insights into classic texts and helping us understand today’s power dynamics through an examination of the past.

Presented with the Chicago Humanities Festival
